<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(*)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> denotes the Company owns its interests in these Centers through an unconsolidated joint venture or through one of the Management Companies.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
financial statements include the results of these Centers for periods subsequent to their acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
February&nbsp;18, 1999, the Company formed Pacific Premier Retail Trust ("PPRT"), a 51/49 joint venture with Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board ("Ontario Teachers"), which closed on the
acquisition of three regional malls, the retail component of a mixed-use development, five contiguous properties and two non-contiguous community shopping centers comprising
approximately 3.6&nbsp;million square feet for a total purchase price of approximately $427.0&nbsp;million. On July&nbsp;12, 1999, the Company closed on the acquisition of the office component
of the mixed-use development for a purchase price of approximately $111.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;2, 1999, Macerich Cerritos, LLC ("Cerritos"), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Macerich Management Company, acquired Los Cerritos Center, a 1,302,374 square foot super regional mall in
Cerritos, California. The total purchase price was $188.0&nbsp;million, which was funded with $120.0&nbsp;million of debt placed concurrently with the closing and a $70.8&nbsp;million loan from
the Company. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;26, 1999, 49% of the membership interests of Macerich Stonewood, LLC ("Stonewood"), Cerritos and Macerich Lakewood, LLC ("Lakewood"), were sold to Ontario Teachers' and </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;23 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=25,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=853169,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DM1141B.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1141_1_24"> </A>
<UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
concurrently Ontario Teachers' and the Company contributed their 99% collective membership interests in Stonewood and Cerritos and 100% of their collective membership interests in Lakewood to PPRT, a
real estate investment trust, owned approximately 51% by the Company and 49% by Ontario Teachers. Lakewood, Stonewood, and Cerritos own Lakewood Mall, Stonewood Mall and Los Cerritos Center,
respectively. The total value of the transaction was approximately $535.0&nbsp;million. The properties were contributed to PPRT subject to existing debt of $322.0&nbsp;million. The net cash
proceeds to the Company were approximately $104.0&nbsp;million, which were used for reduction of debt and for general corporate purposes. Lakewood and Stonewood are referred to herein as the
"Contributed JV Assets." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;27, 1999, Albany Plaza, a 145,462 square foot community center, which was owned 51% by the Macerich Management Company, was sold. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
October&nbsp;29, 1999, Macerich Santa Monica, LLC, a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of the Company, acquired Santa Monica Place, a 560,421 square foot regional mall located in Santa Monica,
California. The total purchase price was $130.8&nbsp;million, which was funded with $80.0&nbsp;million of debt placed concurrently with the closing with the balance funded from proceeds from the
PPRT transaction described above. Santa Monica Place is referred to herein as the "1999 Acquisition Center." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;12, 1999, Eastland Plaza, a 65,313 square foot community center, which was 51% owned by the Macerich Management Company, was sold. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;16, 1999, the Company sold Huntington Center. Huntington Center is a shopping center located in Huntington Beach, California that was purchased by the Company in
December&nbsp;1996. The Center was purchased as part of a package with Fresno Fashion Fair in Fresno, California, and Pacific View (formerly known as Buenaventura Mall) in Ventura, California. The
Center was sold for $48.0&nbsp;million and the net cash proceeds from the sale were used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;30, 2000, Manhattan Village, a 551,847 square foot, regional shopping center, which was owned 10% by the Operating Partnership, was sold. The joint venture sold the property for
$89.0&nbsp;million, including a note receivable from the buyer for $79.0&nbsp;million at a fixed interest rate of 8.75% payable monthly, until its maturity date of September&nbsp;30, 2001. On
December&nbsp;28, 2001, the note receivable was paid down by $5.0&nbsp;million and the maturity date was extended to September&nbsp;30, 2002 at a new fixed interest rate of 9.50%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;14, 2001, Villa Marina Marketplace, a 448,262 square foot community shopping center located in Marina del Rey, California, a wholly-owned property of the Company, was sold. The
center was sold for approximately $99.0&nbsp;million, including the assumption of the existing mortgage of $58.0&nbsp;million, which resulted in a $24.7&nbsp;million gain. The Company used
approximately $26&nbsp;million of the net proceeds from this sale to retire $25.7&nbsp;million of its outstanding convertible subordinated debentures due December&nbsp;2002. The remaining
balance of the proceeds was used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
properties acquired by PPRT and the Management Companies ("Joint Venture Acquisitions") are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The results of these acquisitions are reflected in the
consolidated results of operations of the Company in equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures and the Management Companies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>24&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=26,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=217854,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DM1141B.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1141_1_25"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Many
of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the 1999 Acquisition Centers and the partial sale and contribution of the Contributed JV Assets to PPRT during
1999. Many factors impact the Company's ability to acquire additional properties; including the availability and cost of capital, the overall debt to market capitalization level, interest rates and
availability of potential acquisition targets that meet the Company's criteria. There were no acquisitions in 2001 or 2000 because of market conditions, including the cost of capital and the lack of
attractive opportunities. Accordingly, management is uncertain whether in future years that there will be similar acquisitions and corresponding increases in equity in income of unconsolidated joint
ventures and the Management Companies and Funds From Operations that occurred as a result of the 1999 Acquisition Centers. Pacific View (formerly known as Buenaventura Mall), Crossroads
Mall-Boulder and Parklane Mall are currently under redevelopment or in the case of Pacific View, was recently redeveloped and are referred to herein as the "Redevelopment Centers." All
other Centers, excluding the Redevelopment Centers, are referred to herein as the "Same Centers," unless the context otherwise requires. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Revenues
include rents attributable to the accounting practice of straight lining of rents which requires rent to be recognized each year in an amount equal to the average rent over the term of the
lease, including fixed rent increases over that period. The amount of straight lined rents, included in consolidated revenues, recognized in 2001 was $(0.1) million compared to $0.9&nbsp;million in
2000 and $2.6&nbsp;million in 1999. Additionally, the Company recognized through equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures, $1.4&nbsp;million as its pro rata share of straight lined rents
from joint ventures in 2001 compared to $2.2&nbsp;million in 2000 and $2.3&nbsp;million in 1999. These decreases resulted from the Company structuring the majority of its new leases using annual
Consumer Price Index ("CPI") increases, which generally do not require straight lining treatment. Currently, 29% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases
periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches the
cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's historical growth in revenues, net income and Funds From Operations have been closely tied to the acquisition and redevelopment of shopping centers. Many factors, including those
described above, will affect the Company's ability to acquire and redevelop additional properties in the future. In addition, the following describes some of the other significant factors that could
impact the Company's future results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>General Factors Affecting the Centers; Competition:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Real property investments are subject to varying degrees of risk that may affect the
ability of the Centers to generate sufficient revenues to meet operating and other expenses, including debt service, lease payments, capital expenditures and tenant improvements, and to make
distributions to their owners and the Company's stockholders. Income from shopping center properties may be adversely affected by a number of factors, including: the national economic climate; the
regional and local economy (which may be adversely impacted by plant closings, industry slowdowns, adverse weather conditions, natural disasters, terrorist activities, and other factors); local real
estate conditions (such as an oversupply of, or a reduction in demand for, retail space or retail goods and the availability and creditworthiness of current and prospective tenants); perceptions by
retailers or shoppers of the safety, convenience and attractiveness of the shopping center; and increased costs of maintenance, insurance and operations (including real estate taxes). There are
numerous shopping facilities that compete with the Centers in attracting tenants to lease space, and an increasing number of new retail formats and technologies other than retail shopping centers that
compete with the Centers for retail sales (see </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;25 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=27,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=10436,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DM1141B.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1141_1_26"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
"Business&#150;Competition"). Increased competition could adversely affect the Company's revenues. Income from shopping center properties and shopping center values are also affected by such
factors as applicable laws and regulations, including tax, environmental, safety and zoning laws (see "Business&#150;Environmental Matters"), interest rate levels and the availability and cost
of financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Dependence on Tenants:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's revenues and funds available for distribution would be adversely affected if a significant number of
the Company's lessees were unable (due to poor operating results, bankruptcy or other reasons) to meet their obligations, if the Company were unable to lease a significant amount of space in the
Centers on economically favorable terms, or if for any reason, the Company were unable to collect a significant amount of rental payments. A decision by an Anchor or another significant tenant to
cease operations at a Center could also have an adverse effect on the Company. In addition, mergers, acquisitions, consolidations, dispositions or bankruptcies in the retail industry could result in
the loss of tenants at one or more Centers. (See "Business-Bankruptcy and/or Closure of Retail Stores.") Furthermore, if the store sales of retailers operating in the Centers were to decline
sufficiently, tenants might be unable to pay their minimum rents or expense recovery charges. In the event of a default by a lessee, the Center may also experience delays and costs in enforcing its
rights as lessor. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1141_assets_and_liabilities"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1141_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Assets and Liabilities    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total assets decreased to $2,295&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001 compared to $2,337&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2000 and
$2,404&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 1999. During that same period, total liabilities decreased from $1,626&nbsp;million in 1999 to $1,607&nbsp;million in 2000 and decreased to
$1,584&nbsp;million in 2001. These changes were primarily a result of the partial sale and contribution of the Contributed JV Assets to PPRT, the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace and related debt
transactions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1141_recent_developments"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1141_6"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1141_a._equity_offerings"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1141_7"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>A. Equity Offerings    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On February&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued 1,968,957 common shares with total net proceeds of $52.2&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale of the common shares will be
used principally to finance a portion of the Queens Center expansion and redevelopment project described below under "C. Redevelopment" and for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1141_b._refinancing"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1141_8"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>B. Refinancing    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During 2001, the Company's line of credit facility was increased from $150.0&nbsp;million to $200.0&nbsp;million. The new line of credit matures in May&nbsp;2002 with a
one-year extension option subject to certain terms and conditions. The interest rate ranges from LIBOR plus 1.35% to 1.80%, depending on leverage levels. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;2, 2001, the Company refinanced the debt on Capitola Mall. The prior loan of $36.4&nbsp;million, at a fixed interest rate of 9.25%, was paid in full and a new note was issued for
$48.5&nbsp;million bearing interest at a fixed rate of 7.13% and maturing May&nbsp;15, 2011. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;10, 2001, the Company refinanced the debt on Pacific View. The prior bank construction loan of $89.3&nbsp;million, at a floating interest rate (LIBOR plus 1.75%), was paid in full and
a new permanent loan was issued for $89.0&nbsp;million, which may be increased up to $96.0&nbsp;million subject to certain conditions, bearing interest at a fixed rate of 7.16% and maturing
August&nbsp;31, 2011. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>26&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
On October&nbsp;9, 2001, the Company refinanced the debt on Rimrock Mall. The prior loan of $29.3&nbsp;million, at a fixed interest rate of 7.70%, was paid in full and a new note was issued for
$46.0&nbsp;million bearing interest at a fixed rate of 7.45% and maturing October&nbsp;1, 2011. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_c._redevelopment"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>C. Redevelopment    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In the second quarter of 2001, the new $36.0&nbsp;million expansion opened at Lakewood Mall. The expansion included 60,000 square feet of specialty tenant space and a second
level food court. A new 210,000 square foot Macy's and a new Mervyn's department store anchor the expansion wing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
the third quarter of 2001, the Company completed a $10.0&nbsp;million interior and exterior renovation of Vintage Faire Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;28, 2001, the Company, as part of its proposed redevelopment and expansion of Queens Center, purchased a five-acre parcel of land adjacent to the center. The project
will involve both the renovation of the existing center as well as an expansion of the center from 623,876 square feet to approximately 1&nbsp;million square feet, including the addition of 250,000
square feet of mall shops. Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2002 with completion estimated to be, in phases, through late 2004. Additionally, Swedish apparel retailer Hennes
and Monritz opened a 19,427 square foot store in 2001 at this Center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_d._stock_repurchase_program"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>D. Stock Repurchase Program    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On November&nbsp;10, 2000, the Company's Board of Directors approved a stock repurchase program of up to 3.4&nbsp;million shares of common stock. As of December&nbsp;31,
2000, the Company repurchased 564,000 shares of its common stock at an average price of $19.02 per share. No shares of common stock were repurchased by the Company in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_e._other_events"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>E. Other Events    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On December&nbsp;14, 2001, Villa Marina Marketplace, a 448,262 square foot community shopping center, located in Marina Del Rey, California, a wholly-owned property of the
Company, was sold. The center, which the Company originally acquired on January&nbsp;25, 1996, was sold for approximately $99.0&nbsp;million, including the assumption of the existing mortgage of
$58.0&nbsp;million, which resulted in a $24.7&nbsp;million gain. The Company used approximately $26&nbsp;million of the net proceeds from this sale to retire $25.7&nbsp;million of its
outstanding convertible subordinated debentures due December&nbsp;2002. The remaining balance of the proceeds was used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
March&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company sold Boulder Plaza, a 159,238 square foot community center in Boulder, Colorado for $24.7&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale will be used for general
corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_comparison_of_years_ended_december_31,_2001_and_2000"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_revenues"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 2.9% to $213.9&nbsp;million in 2001 from $207.8&nbsp;million in 2000. Approximately $4.4&nbsp;million of the increase is
attributed to the Same Centers primarily due to releasing space at higher rents and $1.9&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the Redevelopment Centers primarily due to the recently completed
redevelopment at Pacific View Mall. This is partially offset by $0.2&nbsp;million relating to the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;27 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=29,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=248086,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DO1141A.;12',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_do1141_1_28"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $109.2&nbsp;million in 2001 from $104.1&nbsp;million in 2000 due to increased recoverable shopping center and operating expenses. Approximately $5.0&nbsp;million
of the increase is attributable to the Same Centers and $0.4&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the Redevelopment Centers. This is partially offset by $0.3&nbsp;million relating to decreases
from the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Other
income increased to $11.5&nbsp;million in 2001 from $8.2&nbsp;million in 2000. This increase related primarily from parking fees, investment income and new business initiatives such as
advertising revenue and preferred vendor income. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_expenses"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_6"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $110.8&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to $101.7&nbsp;million in 2000. The increase is a result of $3.2&nbsp;million of
increased property taxes, insurance and other recoverable expenses at the Centers and approximately $0.9&nbsp;million relates to increases in bad debt expense and legal fees at the Centers.
Additionally, effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). Expenses for MPMC, LLC for periods
commencing March&nbsp;29, 2001, are now consolidated and represented $5.0&nbsp;million of the change. Prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001, MPMC, LLC was an unconsolidated entity accounted for using the
equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT
general and administrative expenses increased to $6.8&nbsp;million in 2001 from $5.5&nbsp;million in 2000 primarily due to marking to market the stock-based incentive plans. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_interest_expense"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_7"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $109.6&nbsp;million in 2001 from $108.4&nbsp;million in 2000. Capitalized interest was $5.7&nbsp;million in 2001, down from
$7.2&nbsp;million in 2000 primarily due to the reduction of capitalized interest at the recently redeveloped Pacific View Mall. (See "Properties- Mortgage Debt"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_depreciation_and_amortization"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_8"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $66.0&nbsp;million in 2001 from $61.6&nbsp;million in 2000. Approximately $1.4&nbsp;million of the increase is due to greater
depreciation at Pacific View, which recently completed an $89.0&nbsp;million redevelopment and $3.0&nbsp;million relates to additional capital costs at the Same Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_minority_interest"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_9"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 24.8% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership that was not owned by the Company during 2001. This compares to 24.3% not
owned by the Company during 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_income_from_unconsolidated_joi__inc02705"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_10"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income From Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Management Companies    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Management Companies was $32.9&nbsp;million for 2001, compared to income of $30.3&nbsp;million in 2000. A total of
$0.6&nbsp;million of the increase is attributable to the 1999 Joint Venture Acquisitions and the Contributed JV Assets and $2.6&nbsp;million is attributable to the SDG Macerich Properties, L.P.
portfolio. Additionally, income from the Management Companies increased by $3.0&nbsp;million primarily due to MPMC, LLC being consolidated effective March&nbsp;29, 2001. These increases are
partially offset by $2.8&nbsp;million of additional loss as a result of the Company's investment in MerchantWired, LLC compared to 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>28</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

write off of $0.3&nbsp;million of unamortized financing costs in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cumulative Effect of Change in Accounting Principle    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A charge of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2000 was recorded as a result of implementation of SAB 101 at January&nbsp;1, 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_net_income_available_to_common_stockholders"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_14"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders increased to $58.0&nbsp;million in 2001
from $38.0&nbsp;million in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_operating_activities"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_15"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $140.5&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to $121.2&nbsp;million in 2000. The increase is primarily due to consolidating the results of MPMC, LLC
effective March&nbsp;29, 2001 and increased net operating income at the Centers as mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_investing_activities"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_16"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $57.3&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to cash provided by investing activities of $2.1&nbsp;million in 2000. The change resulted
primarily from $24.0&nbsp;million of increased property improvements, renovations and expansion of Centers, tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges in 2001 compared to 2000. Additionally,
joint venture distributions in 2001 were $70.2&nbsp;million less than 2000 due to the distribution of proceeds in 2000 from the additional debt placed on the SDG Macerich Properties, L.P. portfolio.
These decreases are offset by the net cash proceeds received of $39.7&nbsp;million in 2001 from the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_financing_activities"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_17"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow used in financing activities was $93.0&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to cash flow used in financing activities of $127.5&nbsp;million in 2000. The change resulted
primarily from the refinancing of Centers in 2001 (See "Properties-Mortgage Debt"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_ebitda_and_funds_from_operations"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_18"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>EBITDA and Funds From Operations    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily because of the factors mentioned above, EBITDA, including joint ventures at pro rata, increased 2.9% to $323.8&nbsp;million in 2001 from $314.6&nbsp;million in
2000 and Funds from Operations&#150;Diluted increased 4.7% to $175.1&nbsp;million in 2001 from $167.2&nbsp;million in 2000. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_comparison_of_years_ended_december_31,_2000_and_1999"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_19"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 and 1999    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_revenues_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_20"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents decreased by 5.4% to $207.8&nbsp;million in 2000 from $219.7&nbsp;million in 1999. Approximately $24.6&nbsp;million of the decrease related
to the contribution of 100% and 99% of the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;29 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=31,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=25749,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DO1141B.;11',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_do1141_1_30"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
membership interests of Lakewood Mall and Stonewood Mall, respectively, to the PPRT joint venture on October&nbsp;26, 1999. The Company's pro rata share of results from those assets subsequent to
the contribution to PPRT is reflected in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures. The decreases due to the Contributed JV Assets are partially offset by revenue increases of $8.2&nbsp;million
relating to the 1999 acquisition of Santa Monica Place. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
December&nbsp;1999, the Securities and Exchange Committee issued Staff Accounting Bulletin 101, "Revenue Recognition in Financial Statements" ("SAB 101"), which became effective for periods
beginning after December&nbsp;15, 1999. This bulletin modified the timing of revenue recognition for percentage rent received from tenants. This change will defer recognition of a significant amount
of percentage rent for the first three calendar quarters into the fourth quarter. The Company applied this change in accounting principle as of January&nbsp;1, 2000. The cumulative effect of this
change in accounting principle at the adoption date of January&nbsp;1, 2000, including pro rata share of joint ventures, was approximately $1.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $104.1&nbsp;million in 2000 from $99.1&nbsp;million in 1999. The increase resulted from the impact of Santa Monica Place, Pacific View and from the Same Centers.
These increases were partially offset by revenue decreases of $7.7&nbsp;million resulting from the Contributed JV Assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Other
income decreased to $8.2&nbsp;million in 2000 from $8.6&nbsp;million in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_expenses_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_21"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center expenses increased to $101.7&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to $100.3&nbsp;million in 1999. Approximately $6.4&nbsp;million of the increase resulted from
the 1999 acquisition of Santa Monica Place, $3.4&nbsp;million of the increase resulted from increased property taxes and recoverable expenses at the Same Centers. These increases were partially
offset by a decrease of $8.1&nbsp;million from the Contributed JV Assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_interest_expense_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_22"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense decreased to $108.4&nbsp;million in 2000 from $113.3&nbsp;million in 1999. Approximately $7.5&nbsp;million of the decrease is from the Contributed JV
Assets. This decrease is partially offset by the acquisition activity in 1999, which was partially funded with secured debt and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_depreciation_and_amortization_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_23"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $61.6&nbsp;million in 2000 from $61.4&nbsp;million in 1999. Approximately $2.5&nbsp;million of the increase relates primarily
to the 1999 Acquisition Center, which is partially offset by a decrease of $4.6&nbsp;million relating to the Contributed JV Assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_minority_interest_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_24"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 24.3% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership that was not owned by the Company during 2000. This compares to 26.3% not
owned by the Company during 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_income_from_unconsolidated_joi__inc02705_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_25"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income From Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Management Companies    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Management Companies was $30.3&nbsp;million for 2000, compared to income of $25.9&nbsp;million in 1999. A total of
$8.2&nbsp;million of the increase is attributable to the 1999 Joint Venture Acquisitions and the Contributed JV Assets. Additionally, $1.1&nbsp;million is attributable </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>30</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=32,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=610621,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DO1141B.;11',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_do1141_1_31"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
to the gain from the sale of Manhattan Village on September&nbsp;30, 2000. These increases are partially offset by the cumulative effect of the change in accounting principle for percentage rent
required by SAB 101 of $0.8&nbsp;million and additional interest expense from the debt restructuring at SDG Macerich Properties, L.P. of $4.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_gain_(loss)_on_sale_of_assets_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_26"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain (loss) on Sale of Assets    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A loss of $2.8&nbsp;million in 2000 compares to a gain of $96.0&nbsp;million in 1999. The 1999 gain was a result of the Company selling approximately 49% of the membership
interests of Stonewood and Lakewood to Ontario Teachers' in October of 1999 and the Company's sale of Huntington Center on November&nbsp;16, 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_extraordinary_loss_from__do102260"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_27"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Extraordinary Loss from Early Extinguishment of Debt    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2000, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $0.3&nbsp;million which was a result of write offs of $1.3&nbsp;million of unamortized financing
costs and is offset by a gain of $1.0&nbsp;million relating to the Company's purchase and retirement of $10.6&nbsp;million of the Debentures, compared to the write off of $1.5&nbsp;million of
unamortized financing costs in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_cumulative_effect_of_change_in_accounting_principle_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_28"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cumulative Effect of Change in Accounting Principle    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A loss of $1.0&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to no loss in 1999 is a result of implementation of SAB 101 at January&nbsp;1, 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_net_income_available_to_common_stockholders_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_29"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As a result of the foregoing, net income available to common stockholders decreased to $38.0&nbsp;million in 2000 from $110.9&nbsp;million in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_operating_activities_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_30"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $121.2&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to $139.6&nbsp;million in 1999. The decrease is primarily because of decreased net operating income from
the factors mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_investing_activities_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_31"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash generated from investing activities was $2.1&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to cash utilized by investing activities of $243.2&nbsp;million in 1999. The change resulted
primarily from the cash contributions for the joint venture acquisitions of $116.9&nbsp;million in 1999 compared to $4.3&nbsp;million in 2000. This is offset by increases in joint venture
distributions of $104.4&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to $30.0&nbsp;million in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_financing_activities_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_32"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow used in financing activities was $127.5&nbsp;million in 2000 compared to cash provided by financing activities of $119.0&nbsp;million in 1999. The change resulted
primarily from the refinancing of Centers in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_ebitda_and_funds_from_operations_1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_33"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>EBITDA and Funds From Operations    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily because of the factors mentioned above, EBITDA, including joint ventures at pro rata, increased 4.2% to $314.6&nbsp;million in 2000 from $301.8&nbsp;million in
1999 and Funds from Operations&#150;Diluted increased 1.8% to $167.2&nbsp;million in 2000 from $164.3&nbsp;million in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;31 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_do1141_1_32"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1141_liquidity_and_capital_resources"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1141_34"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations and working capital reserves and borrowing under its
line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt service requirements, and to pay dividends to stockholders in
accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be adequate to fund capital expenditures which will not be reimbursed
by tenants, other than non-recurring capital expenditures. The following table summarizes capital expenditures incurred at the wholly-owned Centers for the twelve months ending
December&nbsp;31,: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Management expects similar levels to be incurred in future years for tenant allowances and deferred leasing charges and to incur between $20&nbsp;million to
$50&nbsp;million in 2002 for renovations and expansions, excluding Queens Center expansion which will be separately financed. Capital for major expenditures or major redevelopments has been, and is
expected to continue to be, obtained from equity or debt financings which include borrowings under the Company's line of credit and construction loans. However, many factors impact the Company's
ability to access capital, such as its overall debt level, interest rates, interest coverage ratios and prevailing market conditions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
February&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued 1,968,957 common shares with total net proceeds of $52.2&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale of the common shares will be used principally to
finance a portion of the Queens Center expansion and redevelopment project and for general corporate purposes. The Queens Center expansion and redevelopment is anticipated to cost between
$250&nbsp;million and $275&nbsp;million. The Company is currently negotiating construction and permanent loans, which will be secured by the Queens Center property to finance the remaining project
costs. Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2002 with completion estimated to be, in phases, through late 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company believes that it will have access to the capital necessary to expand its business in accordance with its strategies for growth and maximizing Funds from Operations. The Company presently
intends to obtain additional capital necessary for these purposes through a combination of debt or equity financings, joint ventures and the sale of non-core assets. The Company believes
joint venture arrangements have in the past and may in the future provide an attractive alternative to other forms of financing, whether for acquisitions or other business opportunities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's total outstanding loan indebtedness at December&nbsp;31, 2001 was $2.2&nbsp;billion (including its pro rata share of joint venture debt). This equated to a debt to Total Market
Capitalization (defined as total debt of the Company, including its pro rata share of joint venture debt, plus aggregate market value of outstanding shares of common stock, assuming full conversion of
OP Units and preferred stock into common stock) ratio of approximately 61% at December&nbsp;31, 2001. The Company's debt consists primarily of fixed-rate conventional mortgages payable
secured by individual properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>32</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=34,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=799047,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DO1141B.;11',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dq1141_1_33"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
The Company has filed a shelf registration statement, effective December&nbsp;8, 1997, to sell securities. The shelf registration is for a total of $500&nbsp;million of common stock, common stock
warrants or common stock rights. The Company sold a total of 7,920,181 shares of common stock in 1998 and 1,968,957 shares of common stock in 2002 under this shelf registration. The aggregate offering
price of these transactions was approximately $267.9&nbsp;million, leaving approximately $232.1&nbsp;million available under the shelf registration statement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has an unsecured line of credit for up to $200.0&nbsp;million with a maturity of May&nbsp;2002 with a right to extend the facility for one year subject to certain conditions. It is
anticipated that subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2001, the line of credit will be extended to May&nbsp;2003. There were $159.0&nbsp;million of borrowings outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has $125.1&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures (the "Debentures") which mature December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Debentures are callable on June&nbsp;15, 2002 at par plus
accrued interest. The Company is negotiating a credit facility with its bank group in which the proceeds are intended to retire these Debentures. The Company expects to put this credit facility in
place during 2002 and plans to fully retire the Debentures prior to their maturity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company had cash and cash equivalents available of $26.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has certain guarantees totaling $6.8&nbsp;million relating to its ownership interest in MerchantWired, LLC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has a 2.9% interest in Constellation Real Technologies, LLC, a joint venture investing in real estate technology initiatives and opportunities. The Company funded $1.0&nbsp;million in
2001 and has committed to fund up to an additional $3.0&nbsp;million to this joint venture. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_funds_from_operations"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Funds From Operations    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company believes that the most significant measure of its performance is FFO. FFO is defined by the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts
("NAREIT") to be: Net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from debt restructuring, sales or write-down of assets and cumulative effect of change
in accounting principle, plus depreciation and amortization (excluding depreciation on personal property and amortization of loan and financial instrument costs) and after adjustments for
unconsolidated entities. Adjustments for unconsolidated entities are calculated on the same basis. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations, as defined by GAAP, and is not necessarily
indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may not be comparable to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;33 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dq1141_1_34"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. The following reconciles net income available to common stockholders to FFO: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Calculated based upon basic net income as adjusted to reach basic FFO. Weighted average number of shares includes the weighted average shares of common
stock outstanding for 2001 assuming the conversion of all outstanding OP Units. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, 11.2&nbsp;million of OP Units were outstanding.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> The computation of FFO-diluted and diluted average number of shares outstanding includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted
stock using the treasury method. The debentures are dilutive at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000 and are included in the FFO calculation. On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold
$100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;17, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The preferred stock can be converted
on a one-for-one basis for common stock. The preferred shares are assumed converted for purposes of 2001 and 2000 FFO-diluted as they are dilutive to that
calculation.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included in minimum rents were rents attributable to the accounting practice of straight lining of rents. The amount of straight lining of rents that impacted
minimum rents was ($72,029) for 2001, $865,259 for 2000 and $2,628,000 for 1999. The decline in straight-lining of rents from 1999 to 2001 is due to the Company structuring its new leases using rent
increases tied to the change in CPI rather than using contractually fixed rent increases. CPI increases do not generally require straight-lining of rent treatment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_inflation"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Inflation    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In the last three years, inflation has not had a significant impact on the Company because of a relatively low inflation rate. Most of the leases at the Centers
have rent adjustments periodically through the lease </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>34</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=36,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=893211,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DQ1141A.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1141_1_35"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
term. These rent increases are either in fixed increments or based on increases in the CPI. In addition, about 8%-12% of the leases expire each year, which enables the Company to replace
existing leases with new leases at higher base rents if the rents of the existing leases are below the then existing market rate. Additionally, most of the leases require the tenants to pay their pro
rata share of operating expenses. This reduces the Company's exposure to increases in costs and operating expenses resulting from inflation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_seasonality"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Seasonality    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The shopping center industry is seasonal in nature, particularly in the fourth quarter during the holiday season when retailer occupancy and retail sales are
typically at their highest levels. In addition, shopping malls achieve a substantial portion of their specialty (temporary retailer) rents during the holiday season and the majority of percentage rent
is recognized in the fourth quarter. As a result of the above, plus the change in accounting principle discussed below for percentage rent, earnings are generally higher in the fourth quarter of each
year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_statement_on_critical_accounting_policies"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Statement on Critical Accounting Policies    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") recently issued disclosure guidance for "critical accounting policies." The SEC defines "critical accounting
policies" as those that require application of management's most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are
inherently uncertain and may change in subsequent periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the
reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgements on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectable accounts and
estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following
policies could be deemed to be critical within the SEC definition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_revenue_recognition_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue Recognition:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the amount
recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Currently, 29% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases periodically
throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches the cash revenue
from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized on an accrual basis. Recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes,
insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_property_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_6"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on redevelopment and construction projects are
capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;35 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=37,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=815583,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DQ1141A.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1141_1_36"> </A>
<BR><BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Realized gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="73%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>initial term of related lease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company assesses whether there has been an impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating income,
trends and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the
leases. The Company may recognize an impairment loss if the income stream is not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value and
the fair value of a center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_deferred_charges_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_7"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Cost relating to financing of
shopping center properties are deferred and
amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method. The range of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="73%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred lease costs</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred financing costs</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1-15 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the
reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgements on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectable accounts and
estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_new_pronouncements_issued"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_8"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>New Pronouncements Issued    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In December&nbsp;1999, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin 101, "Revenue Recognition in Financial Statements" ("SAB 101"),
which became effective for periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 1999. This bulletin modified the timing of revenue recognition for percentage rent received from tenants. This change will defer
recognition of a significant amount of percentage rent for the first three calendar quarters into the fourth quarter. The Company applied this change in accounting principle as of January&nbsp;1,
2000. The cumulative effect of this change in accounting principle at the adoption </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>36</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=38,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=487886,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DQ1141A.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1141_1_37"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
date of January&nbsp;1, 2000, including the pro rata share of joint ventures, was approximately $1.8&nbsp;million. If the Company had recorded percentage rent using the methodology prescribed in
SAB 101, the Company's net income available to common stockholders would have been reduced by $1.3&nbsp;million or $0.02 per diluted share, $1.1&nbsp;million or $0.025 per diluted share and
$0.6&nbsp;million or $0.016 per diluted share for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 1999, 1998 and 1997, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
June&nbsp;1998, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standard ("SFAS") 133, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,"
("SFAS&nbsp;133") which requires companies to record derivatives on the balance sheet, measured at fair value. Changes in the fair values of those derivatives are accounted for depending on the use
of the derivative and whether it qualifies for hedge accounting. The key criterion for hedge accounting is that the hedging relationship must be highly effective in achieving offsetting changes in
fair value or cash flows. In June&nbsp;1999, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;137, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," which delayed the implementation of SFAS&nbsp;133 from
January&nbsp;1, 2000 to January&nbsp;1, 2001. In June&nbsp;2000, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;138, "Accounting for Certain Derivative Instruments and Certain Hedging Activities&#150;an
Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133," ("SFAS138"), which amended the accounting and reporting standards of SFAS&nbsp;133. As a result of the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;133 on January&nbsp;1,
2001, the Company recorded a transition adjustment of $7.1&nbsp;million to accumulated other comprehensive income related to treasury rate lock transactions settled in prior years. The entire
transition adjustment was reflected in the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2001.The Company expects that $1.3&nbsp;million will be reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive income to earnings
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
June&nbsp;2001, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;143, "Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations," which is effective for fiscal years beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2002. The statement
provides accounting and reporting standards for recognizing obligations related to asset retirement costs associated with the retirement of tangible long-lived assets. Under this
statement, legal obligations associated with the retirement of long-lived assets are to be recognized at their fair value in the period in which they are incurred if a reasonable estimate
of fair value can be made. The fair value of the asset retirement costs is capitalized as part of the carrying amount of the long-lived asset and expensed using a systematic and rational
method over the assets' useful life. Any subsequent changes to the fair value of the liability will be expensed. The Company does not believe that the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;143 will have a
material impact on its consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;141, "Business Combinations" ("SFAS&nbsp;141"). SFAS&nbsp;141 requires that the purchase method of accounting be used for all business
combinations for which the date of acquisition is after June&nbsp;30, 2001. SFAS&nbsp;141 also establishes specific criteria for the recognition of intangible assets. The Company has determined
that the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;141 will not have an impact on its consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
October&nbsp;2001, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;144, "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets" ("SFAS&nbsp;144"). SFAS&nbsp;144 addresses financial
accounting and reporting for the impairment or disposal of long-lived assets. This statement supersedes SFAS&nbsp;121, "Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and
for Long-Lived Assets to be Disposed of" ("SFAS&nbsp;121"). SFAS&nbsp;144 establishes a single accounting model, based on the framework established in SFAS&nbsp;121, for
long-lived assets to be disposed of by sale. The Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;144 on January&nbsp;1, 2002. The Company has determined that the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;144 will not have a
material impact on its consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;37 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=39,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=964160,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DQ1141A.;18',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:28' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1141_1_38"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1141_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02669"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1141_9"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's primary market risk exposure is interest rate risk. The Company has managed and will continue to manage interest rate risk by (1)&nbsp;maintaining a
conservative ratio of fixed rate, long-term debt to total debt such that variable rate exposure is kept at an acceptable level, (2)&nbsp;reducing interest rate exposure on certain
long-term variable rate debt through the use of interest rate caps with appropriately matching maturities, (3)&nbsp;using treasury rate locks where appropriate to fix rates on
anticipated debt transactions, and (4)&nbsp;taking advantage of favorable market conditions for long-term debt and/or equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table sets forth information as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 concerning the Company's long term debt obligations, including principal cash flows by scheduled maturity, weighted average
interest rates and estimated fair value ("FV"): </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<TD WIDTH="1%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The $159.0&nbsp;million of variable debt maturing in 2002 represents the outstanding borrowings under the Company's credit facility. It is anticipated that subsequent to
December&nbsp;31, 2001, the line of credit will be extended to May&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;15, 2002, the Company has $125.1&nbsp;million of Debentures which will mature. The Debentures are callable on June&nbsp;15, 2002 at par plus accrued interest. The Company is
negotiating a credit facility with its bank group in which the proceeds are intended to retire these Debentures. The Company expects to put this credit facility in place during 2002 and plans to fully
retire the Debentures prior to their maturity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, the Company has assessed the market risk for its variable rate debt and believes that a 1% increase in interest rates would decrease future earnings and cash flows by approximately
$3.0&nbsp;million per year based on $300.2&nbsp;million outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
fair value of the Company's long term debt is estimated based on discounted cash flows at interest rates that management believes reflect the risks associated with long term debt of similar risk
and duration. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>38</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>There is hereby incorporated by reference the information which appears under the caption "Executive Compensation" in the Company's definitive proxy statement for its 2002
Annual Meeting of Stockholders; provided, however, that the Report of the Compensation Committee on executive compensation and the Stock Performance Graph set forth therein shall not be incorporated
by reference herein, in any of the Company's prior or future filings under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, or the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934, as amended, except to the extent the Company specifically incorporates such report or stock performance graph by reference therein and shall not be otherwise deemed filed under either of
such Acts. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=43,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=637028,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]DS1141A.;12',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;08:32' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fb1141_1_42"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fb1141_report_of_independent_accountants"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fb1141_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of The Macerich Company: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
our opinion, based on our audits and the report of other auditors, the consolidated financial statements listed in the index appearing under Item 14(a)(1) present fairly, in all material respects,
the financial position of The Macerich Company (the "Company") at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. In addition, in our opinion, the financial statement schedule listed in the
index appearing under Item 14(a)(4) presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements. These
financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management; our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and financial
statement schedule based on our audits. We did not audit the financial statements of SDG Macerich Properties, L.P. (the "Partnership"), the investment in which is reflected in the accompanying
consolidated financial statements using the equity method of accounting. The investment in the Partnership represents approximately 7.3% and 7.2% of the Company's consolidated total assets at
December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, respectively, and the equity in income represents approximately 21.7%, 22.1% and 13.7% of the related consolidated net income for each of the three years in the
period ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Those statements were audited by other auditors whose report thereon has been furnished to us, and our opinion expressed herein, insofar as it relates to the
amounts included for the Partnership, is based solely on the report of the other auditors. We conducted our audits of these statements in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the
United States of America, which require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes
examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used
and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits and the report of other auditors provide a reasonable basis for
our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
discussed in Note&nbsp;2 to the consolidated financial statements, effective January&nbsp;1, 2000, the Company adopted Staff Accounting Bulletin 101. Additionally, as discussed in Note&nbsp;2
to the consolidated financial statements, effective January&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No.&nbsp;133. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>PricewaterhouseCoopers
LLP </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Los
Angeles, CA<BR>
February&nbsp;13, 2002 </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>42&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>46&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=48,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=391870,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]FE1141B.;13',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:33' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fg1141_1_47"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>THE MACERICH COMPANY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> (Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>1. Organization and Basis of Presentation:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the "Company") commenced operations effective with the completion of its initial public offering (the "IPO") on March&nbsp;16, 1994. The
Company is the sole general partner of and, assuming conversion of the redeemable preferred stock, holds a 79% ownership interest in The Macerich Partnership, L. P. (the "Operating Partnership"). The
interests in the Operating Partnership are known as OP Units. OP Units not held by the Company are redeemable, subject to certain restrictions, on a one-for-one basis for the
Company's common stock or cash at the Company's option. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company was organized to qualify as a real estate investment trust ("REIT") under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The 21% limited partnership interest of the Operating Partnership
not owned by the Company is reflected in these financial statements as minority interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
property management, leasing and redevelopment of the Company's portfolio is provided by the three management companies, Macerich Property Management Company, LLC, a Delaware limited liability
company, Macerich Manhattan Management Company, a California corporation, and Macerich Management Company, a California corporation (collectively, the "Management Companies"). The term "Management
Companies" includes Macerich Property Management Company prior to its merger with Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC") on March&nbsp;29, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_basis_of_presentation_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Basis Of Presentation:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The consolidated financial statements of the Company include the accounts of the Company and the Operating Partnership. The properties in which the Operating Partnership does
not have a controlling interest in, and the Management Companies (excluding MPMC, LLC), have been accounted for under the equity method of accounting. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company
consolidated the accounts for MPMC, LLC. These entities are reflected on the Company's consolidated financial statements as "Investments in joint ventures and the Management Companies." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_cash_and_cash_equivalents_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash And Cash Equivalents:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company considers all highly liquid investments with an original maturity of 90&nbsp;days or less when purchased to be cash equivalents, for which cost approximates fair
value. Included in cash is restricted cash of $3,495 at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and $1,464 at December&nbsp;31, 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_tenant_receivables_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tenant Receivables:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Included in tenant receivables are allowances for doubtful accounts of $727 and $700 at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;47 </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=49,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=792554,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]FG1141A.;20',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:33' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1141_1_48"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_revenues_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Rental income was decreased by $72 in 2001 and increased by $865 in 2000 and $2,628 in 1999 due to the
straight lining of rent adjustment. Percentage rents are recognized on an accrual basis. Recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are
recognized as revenues in the period the applicable expenses are incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Management Companies provide property management, leasing, corporate, redevelopment and acquisition services to affiliated and non-affiliated shopping centers. In consideration for
these services, the Management Companies receive monthly management fees generally ranging from 1.5% to 5% of the gross monthly rental revenue of the properties managed. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_property_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on redevelopment and construction projects are
capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which include HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Realized gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>initial term of related lease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7&nbsp;years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company assesses whether there has been an impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future
operating income, trends and prospects, as well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under
the terms of the leases. The Company may recognize an impairment loss if the income stream is not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the
carrying value and the fair value of a center. Management believes no such impairment has occurred in its net property carrying values at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><B>48&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=1><B>MACERICH 2001 Financial Statements </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=50,EFW="2073846",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=469305,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK020:[02WLA1.02WLA1141]FG1141A.;20',USER='DMALONE',CD='23-MAR-2002;07:33' -->
<A NAME="page_fg1141_1_49"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fg1141_deferred_charges_"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fg1141_6"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:    <BR>  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Cost relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method. The
range of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
